p: The hole board test is another valuable paradigm to evaluate the anxiolytic response of mice under unfavorable conditions. The reluctance of the head dipping tendency is regarded as anxiogenic behavior of mice, whereas spontaneous exploration of visiting holes (head dipping) indicates the anxiolytic nature of plant extract [ 59]. During this study, the administration of MEBJ increased the tendency of head dipping significantly at the dose of 200 mg/kg (P < 0.01) and 400 mg/kg (P < 0.001) as compared with the control group ( Figure 2G). The number of head dipping was noted 34.2 ± 1.85 for 200 mg/kg and 48.8 ± 1.6 for 400 mg/kg, while standard drug (diazepam) increased the head dipping to 68.2 ± 1.53. Therefore, the results from EPM and HB tests suggest that MEBJ possesses potential anxiolytic activity.
